repnme.cdata!: Senegal - Second Small Rural Operations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, and
            institutional development impacts are modest. The Bank
            performance is rated unsatisfactory, given a weak design,
            inadequate supervision - particularly in terms of skills mix
            - and, implementation problems, which regardless of the
            rightful decision to suspend disbursements, four years
            elapsed until effectively setting the Senegalese Association
            for the Promotion of Small Rural Development Projects as the
            new implementing agency. Likewise, performance by the
            Borrower is assessed as unsatisfactory, in light of costly
            implementation interruptions, which led to poor financial
            management practices, in addition to undue political
            interference conducive to below par subprojects. A number of
            well known generic lessons are drawn from the project,
            namely, the need for a project design, suitable for local
            implementation capacities; the need for full beneficiary
            participation in design, and implementation; clearly defined
            accountability, and responsibility within a detailed
            implementation plan; and, the critical need for adequate
            management, monitoring, and reporting systems. Additionally,
            implementation delays do not necessarily increase investment
            costs, but it does reduce financial, and economic returns,
            de-motivating investor confidence; and, lack of serious
            government commitment should preclude restructuring of an operation.

repnme.cdata!: Senegal - Second Small Rural Operations Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is the second phase of the
            First Rural Operations project, a national program
            supporting the development of small rural activities. As
            such it will continue the process of channelling funds and
            technical services to small groups of rural people, who will
            provide labor and some cash for the development of several
            types of productive activities. The project introduces
            various producer groups to new technology and new activities
            and reinforces the local capacity for identification and
            preparation of small rural projects. Eight subprojects have
            been appraised, covering cereal, vegetable, fruit and honey
            production in different regions of the country. The project
            will finance land development works, irrigation systems and
            equipment, vehicles, inputs, training of farmer groups and
            staff, and operating costs of subprojects and a management
            unit. It also includes a provision for identifying and
            financing new subprojects in the course of project
            implementation. Beneficiaries are expected to make important
            contributions in cash and kind to the investments, replace
            all medium-term assets and bear all recurrent operating costs.
